title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. Administrative funding deadlines are also extended to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified in Section 3. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2018, 2019, and 2020. The Small Business Act is amended to require specific expenditure percentages for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2020, 2021, 2022, and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to set expenditure percentages for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2018 and beyond, with increments from 0.50 percent in 2018-2019 to 0.60 percent in 2022 and subsequent years. The Small Business Act is amended to set expenditure percentages for SBIR funding in fiscal years 2018 and beyond, with increments from 0.50 percent in 2018-2019 to 0.60 percent in 2022 and subsequent years. Reporting requirements are outlined in Section 4. The Small Business Act is amended to change reporting requirements, with reports now due by December 31 and March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act is amended to update reporting requirements, with reports now due by March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act is amended to update reporting requirements, with reports now due by March 30 of each year for agencies to submit to the Administration. The Small Business Act is amended to update reporting requirements, with reports now due by March 30 of each year for agencies to submit to the Administration. The amendments specify the deadline for submitting reports annually. The Small Business Act is amended to update reporting requirements, with reports now due by specific dates each year for agencies to submit to the Administration. The Small Business Act is amended to require Federal agencies to report on the use of administrative funds annually by March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act now mandates that Federal agencies must report on their use of administrative funds annually by March 30. Failure to submit the report will exempt the agency from certain requirements until the report is submitted along with a plan for timely reporting in the future. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended to make changes to subsections (j)(2) and (p)(2)(B), including redesignating subparagraphs and clauses, and striking certain subparagraphs and clauses. The Small Business Act is amended to make changes to Phase I and Phase II awards under the SBIR or STTR program, limiting Phase I awards to $150,000 and Phase II awards to $1,000,000. The Small Business Act limits Phase I awards under the STTR program to $150,000 and Phase II awards to $1,000,000, with adjustments for inflation. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to require certain insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies the eligibility of certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify the eligibility of certain small businesses for receiving awards under the SBIR program. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify that small business concerns described in subparagraphs (B), (C), and (D) of section 3(p)(3) are eligible to receive awards under the SBIR program. Small business concerns in subparagraphs (B), (C), and (D) of section 3(p)(3) are eligible for awards under the STTR program. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program for eligible entities to receive a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program for eligible entities to receive a second sequential SBIR award. Covered agencies may not use more than 5 percent of their total SBIR funds for this program. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program limits covered agencies to using 5 percent of their SBIR budget for awards and will end on September 30, 2022. The Administrator will require a matching requirement for eligible entities receiving awards. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires eligible entities to secure a matching amount from a third-party investor to receive an award. Ineligible funding sources cannot be used to meet this matching requirement. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program requires eligible entities to secure matching funds from a third-party investor to receive an award. Awards must not exceed certain limitations and will be distributed during the Phase II award period. To be selected for a second sequential SBIR award, entities must submit an application. To receive a second sequential SBIR award under a commercialization assistance pilot program, an eligible entity must submit an application with required information and matching funding details. The funds awarded can only be used for commercialization purposes. The commercialization assistance pilot program awards funds for research and development activities that accelerate commercialization. Recipients are determined based on the potential impact of the supplemental funds on the applicant. The pilot program awards supplemental funds to aid commercialization efforts by evaluating the proposed plan's feasibility and potential societal benefits. The pilot program evaluates small businesses' progress in Phase II activities, third-party funding expectations, and the likelihood of commercial and societal benefits. The Comptroller General will provide an evaluation report within 3 years of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016 enactment. The Comptroller General will submit an evaluative report to relevant committees summarizing activities and results of commercialization assistance pilot programs. The Comptroller General will submit an evaluative report summarizing the results of commercialization assistance pilot programs, including awards received, commercialization rates, growth in employment and revenue, and comparison of success with non-participants. The evaluative report on commercialization assistance pilot programs will include a comparison of success between pilot program participants and non-matching Phase II award recipients, demographic information of participant companies, funds usage at each agency, third-party funding distribution, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for improvement. The evaluative report on commercialization assistance pilot programs will include an analysis of program effectiveness at each participating agency, recommendations for improvement, and definitions for covered agency and eligible entity. The term 'eligible third-party investors' refers to small business concerns, venture capital firms, individual investors, non-SBIR Federal, State, or local governments, or any combination thereof. The term 'ineligible sources' includes specific entities that are not eligible for certain benefits. The term 'ineligible sources' refers to funding sources that are not eligible for certain benefits, such as the awardee's internal research funds, non-cash funding, funding from owners or affiliates, and funding obtained through loans or debt obligations. SEC. 9. INCREASED UNDERSERVED POPULATION PARTICIPATION WAIVER REMOVED. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to enhance outreach and technical assistance for federal agencies participating in the program. This includes carrying out policy directives and increasing the participation of states with historically low levels of SBIR awards. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to ensure consistency in the Act. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to enhance outreach and technical assistance for federal agencies participating in the program. A conforming amendment is made to ensure consistency in the Act by removing certain provisions.
